data.body:

1. Have several files open
2. Click from Chrome into Atom
3. Crash (only once so far though)

**Electron Version**: 0.37.8

data.title: Atom menus unreadable (both background and text are white) on Windows using high contrast theme
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [X] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [X] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [X] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [X] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [X] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [X] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?

For more information on how to write a good [bug report](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-bug-report) or [enhancement request](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#how-do-i-submit-a-good-enhancement-suggestion), see the `CONTRIBUTING` guide.
### Description

![2016-09-19 20_23_20-untitled atom](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5874526/18641967/74aed9e0-7ea7-11e6-8301-c24b27e38639.png)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Use Windows (tested on Windows 10)
2. Enable a High Contrast theme
3. Launch Atom

**Expected behavior:** Menus should be legible 

**Actual behavior:** Menus are illegible, making Atom unusable
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

```
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 3.5.2
git 2.8.2.windows.1
visual studio 2015
```

This can be traced back to (see https://bugs.chromium.org/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=570698), please bump Chrome to resolve (verified fixed in `M49-49.0.2623.108`).

data.title: Bracket matching is hidden by line background-color (due to z-index)
OS X - Open File dialog does not show after closing editor window.
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [x] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [x] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)? 
- [x] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [x] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [x] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [x] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

The Open File dialog doesn't show if you close the editor window upon starting the application, and then try to open a file. 

![atom-no-openy-file](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/1438/18634500/160f02fa-7e4f-11e6-843e-6e32861d5786.gif)
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Open atom with no folder/file arguments.
2. Close the default window with it's blank editor tab ( or `Cmd+W`, `Cmd+W` to close the empty editor tab, and then the window)
3. Try to open a new file via the `File->Open...` menu, or `Cmd+O`

**Expected behavior:** An open file dialog to pop up.

**Actual behavior:** Nothing happens.
### Versions

OS X 10.11.6

```
 $ atom --version
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0

$ apm --version
apm  1.12.5
npm  3.10.5
node 4.4.5
python 2.7.11
git 2.8.3
```

### Description

Tried to download Atom on my laptop that has Windows 10. Resulted in "Installation has Failed" message. After looking on forum, decided to open an Issue as per instructions here: https://discuss.atom.io/t/having-windows-installation-problems/26498

1. Went to Atom home page. Clicked Download.
2. Ran AtomSetup.exe
3. The "please wait while Atom is installing" window opened

data.title: `atom --help` is too opinionated about terminal width
data.body: A picture is worth a thousand words:

data.title: [UX] Listing "Featured packages" below search results is confusing
data.body:
Many applications these days perform search while you type. Since atom is listing featured packages under the search dialog (when you try to install a new package) it gives an initial impression that the the featured packages listing is the result of your search (if you just type your query without hitting enter). This is very confusing. I would suggest either:

a) implementing search while you type functionality
b) remove the featured packages from the search/install page

### Description

### Steps to Reproduce

data.title: Improve the "Save As" file path
data.body:
Currently in Atom when you do a "Save As" (or save a new file) it will have a default name of "Untitled".

Sublime had a feature that would take the first 50 characters of your file and make that the default file name when using "Save As".  I loved this feature because when I was creating new files I would tend to start them with something that could be a useful file name.

This is still a work in progress, but I wanted to get the conversation started.

I am trying to find if there is a good way to do some kind of a hook so that the default "Save As" file name could be configured via a package.

I don't think it is possible right now but I might have missed something.  This is my first stab at implementing a feature in Atom. Any help would be appreciated.

Here is an example:

![](https://media.giphy.com/media/3o7TKsxO1p8iWGeJws/giphy.gif)

data.title: editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor return undefined as special condition
data.body:
### Steps to Reproduce

Given a markdown file with **a list** with link:

```
- _https://github.com/atom/atom/issues/new
```

Where `_` represents the cursor position (at the start of the link, and after the list head `-`)

And I try to get the buffer range for scope link:

```
editor = atom.workspace.getActiveTextEditor()

cursor = editor.getLastCursor()
cursor.getScopeDescriptor().getScopesArray()
// => ["source.gfm", "markup.underline.link.http.hyperlink"]

// since markup.underline.link.http.hyperlink scope is there, when i try to get the buffer range
editor.bufferRangeForScopeAtCursor('markup.underline.link.http.hyperlink')
// => undefined
```

**Expected behavior:**

It should return the correct buffer range. 

The undefined buffer range only happens in list links. E.g. `- link` or `- [ ] link`.
### Versions

```
Atom    : 1.10.2
Electron: 0.37.8
Chrome  : 49.0.2623.75
Node    : 5.10.0
```

data.title: Lookbehinds not supported in Task instances
data.body:
Recent versions of Chromium include support for lookbehinds in regular expressions:

``` js
/(?<=a)b/.test("ab"); // -> true
```

This includes the one Atom v1.10 uses, which you can confirm by running the above snippet in your devtools.

However, [Task](https://atom.io/docs/api/v1.10.2/Task) instances seem to run using an older version of Node, because they throw TypeErrors if given regex with lookbehinds in them.
### Steps to reproduce
1. Save the following snippet to `~/Desktop/scan-test.js` (or something similar):
   
   ``` js
   module.exports = function(){
       let done = this.async();
       /(?<=a)b/.test("ab");
       done();
   };
   ```
2. Open the dev tools and run:
   
   ``` js
   require("atom").Task.once(`${process.env.HOME}/Desktop/scan-test.js`);
   ```
### Expectation

Nothing.
### Reality

```
/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:52 Invalid regular expression:
/(?<=a)b/: Invalid group SyntaxError: Invalid regular expression: /(?<=a)b/: Invalid group
    at Object.module.exports (scan-test.js:3:2)
    at process.<anonymous> (/Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task-bootstrap.js:84:10)
    at emitTwo (events.js:100:13)
    at process.emit (events.js:185:7)
    at handleMessage (internal/child_process.js:718:10)
    at Pipe.channel.onread (internal/child_process.js:444:11)
    (anonymous function) @ /Applications/Atom.app/Contents/Resources/app.asar/src/task.js:52
```

### Description

Atom's Auto Detect is detecting the **ISO-8859** file below as a **Windows 1251** encoding resulting the word "Documenta****o" to open as "Documenta****o".

**Content of the [western-iso-8859-1.txt](https://github.com/atom/encoding-selector/files/477390/western-iso-8859-1.txt) file:**

``` bash
western-iso-8859-1.txt: PHP script, ISO-8859 text, with CRLF line terminators
```

data.title: Using eval() in Web Worker
data.body:
I'm attempting to port some code which works in browsers to create a package for Atom. When eval() is used inside  Worker code, it generates the standard EvalError due to the Content Security Policy script-src: 'self', i.e., no 'unsafe-eval'.

If the code was on the main thread, it could use the common 'loophole' based on the 'vm' module. But Node cannot be used inside Worker's and this is unlikely to change due to thread safety issues (electron Issue #797).

Two possible ways around this problem:
1. Provide a mechanism by which Workers can use the standard loophole, e.g., pre-install 'vm' or equivalent into WorkerGlobalSpace.
2. Provide a mechanism to redefine the security policy within a package.

But I'm open to other suggestions, including use of some Atom feature that I haven't found yet. I'm not looking for an alternative to Workers; I'd like to reuse the code that already works in browsers.

data.title: workspace.getActiveTextEditor() etc don't work if the text editor is not a PaneItem
data.body:
The [docs](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/v1.10.2/src/workspace.coffee#L646-L658) for `workspace.getTextEditors()` suggests that _all_ `TextEditors` anywhere will be returned, just as `workspace.getActiveTextEditor()` should seemingly return the currently active `TextEditor` no matter what.

This is obviously at odds with the implementation, which only considers `TextEditors` which are registered as `PaneItem`s. In the [ink package](https://github.com/JunoLab/atom-ink/), we have a `Console`-class, which extends `PaneItem` and can contain `TextEditor`s as input cells (those are properly registered, I think), but one can't access them via one of the commands above (also see [#75](https://github.com/JunoLab/atom-ink/issues/75) for why this is problematic).

So either the documentation should clarify that only certain `TextEditor`s will be considered or the implementation should be changed to searching the `TextEditorRegistry` or something like that. 

I can have a look at implementing this if you think that'd be a proper solution.

data.title: Improve support for international keyboards
data.body:
Closes https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/issues/35
Closes https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/issues/34

This PR includes a new version of `atom-keymap` with changes described in https://github.com/atom/atom-keymap/pull/144.

The basic idea is that we will never shadow the ability to type an ASCII character with any key binding. Most of this logic is handled in `atom-keymap` and is describe in the above PR.

In addition to the keymap changes, we are forced to omit keyboard shortcuts for application menu items if there's a possibility they could interfere with typing `AltGraph`-modified characters on international layouts. This means that `alt-` bindings on Mac and `ctrl-alt-` bindings on Windows won't show up in the menu, but the bindings will still work so long as they don't conflict.

I'd appreciate it if international users could give this a try by downloading binaries from the build provider for their platform. You can find links to builds of this PR in the build status section at the bottom of this page, then navigate to the "artifacts" section:
- For Windows, go to AppVeyor artifiacts
- For Mac, go to Circle artifacts
- For Linux, go to Travis, where you can find the S3 download URLs in the build log
